We find substantial variation in the absorption profiles, which likely reflects the complex morphology of inhomogeneously-distributed, clumpy gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07422v1.title: A variable star population in the open cluster NGC 6791 observed by the Kepler spacecraft
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07422v1.summary: We present the list of variable stars we found in the Kepler superstamp data                covering approximately 9 arcminutes from the central region of NGC 6791. In total we found278 variable objects, among which 17 binaries, 45 pulsators, 62 rotational and five unclassified variables are cluster members. Only three objects show significant orbital period fluctuations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v1.title: Mapping the Decline with Redshift of Dusty Star-forming Galaxies Using JWST and SCUBA-2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v1.summary: We use JWST NIRCam observations from 1.5 to 4.44 micron of the massive Lensing cluster field A2744. We show that there is a strong drop (a factor of around 5) in the ratio of the far-infrared luminosity to the bolometric luminosity at therest-frame 5000 A between z<4 and z>4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07410v1.title: Relative Alignment Between Magnetic Fields and Molecular Gas Structure in Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07410v1.summary: We compare the structure of synthetic dust polarization with syntheticmolecular line emission from radiative transfer calculations using a turbulent collapsing-cloud magnetohydrodynamics simulation. We find good agreement between these results and sub-Alfv\'enic simulations when viewed with the magnetic field in the plane of the sky.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07387v1.title: Searching for the sources of excess extragalactic dispersion of FRBs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07387v1.summary: The FLIMFLAM survey is collecting spectroscopic data of field galaxies near fast radio burst (FRB) sightlines to constrain key parameters describing the distribution of matter in the Universe. In this work, we leverage the survey data to determine the source of the excess extragalactic dispersion measure(DM)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07378v1.title: Dark-ages reionization and galaxy formation simulation -- XXI. Constraining the evolution of the ionizing escape fraction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07378v1.summary: The fraction of ionizing photons that escape their host galaxies to ionizeHydrogen in the inter-galactic medium (IGM) is a critical parameter in analyses of the reionization era. In this paper we use the Meraxes semi-analytic galaxyformation model to infer the mean ionizing photon escape fraction and its dependence on galaxy properties. As a function of redshift, we find that reionizing is dominated by the smaller galaxies with high escape fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07376v1.title: Metal Factories in the Early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07376v1.summary: We measured the mass of metals in 13 submillimetre galaxies at z~4 in which the gas, based on previous observations, lies in a cold rotating disk. We used the dynamical masses of these galaxies to set an upper limit on the metal abundance of the interstellar medium. Using two chemical evolution models, we show that the high metal masses and metal abundances are what is expected shortly after the formation of a top-heavy IMF.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07375v1.title: On the Tidal Capture of White Dwarfs by Intermediate-mass Black Holes in Dense Stellar Environments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07375v1.summary: intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) are the missing link betweenstellar-mass and supermassive black holes. Tidaldisruptions of white dwarfs (WDs) provide a unique smoking gunthat could finally probe the existence of IMBH's beyond any reasonable doubt.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07369v1.title: Updated radial velocities and new constraints on the nature of the unseen source in NGC1850 BH1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07369v1.summary: A black hole candidate orbiting a luminous star in the Large Magellanic Cloud cluster NGC 1850 ($\sim100$Myr) has recently been reported. An alternative explanation has been suggested for the system: a bloated post-mass transfer star with a more massive, yet luminous companion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v1.title: An HI story of galaxies in Abell 2626 and beyond
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v1.summary: The HI deficiency of a galaxy is strongly correlated with the projected distance from the centre of A2626. The substructure galaxies tend to be more asymmetric than the isolated galaxies in the cluster. galaxies in all three environments have slightly lower star-formation rates than the typical SFR for normal galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10115v1.title: 3D hydrodynamics simulations of core convection in supermassive main-sequence stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10115v1.summary: Supermassive stars could be the progenitors of the first supermassive blackholes. Their interiors are in a regime where radiation pressure dominates theequation of state. We conclude that the radiation pressure-dominated nature of the star's interior does not noticeably affect the behaviour of convection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v1.title: Reconstructing Galactic magnetic fields from local measurements for backtracking ultra-high-energy cosmic rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v1.summary: Ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) are highly energetic particles with energies exceeding $10^{18}$ eV. Identifying their sources and production mechanism can provide insight into many open questions in astrophysics and high energy physics. The Galactic magnetic field (GMF) deflects UHECR, and the high uncertainties in our current understanding of the $3$-dimensional structure of the GMF does not permit us to accurately determine their true arrival direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10077v1.title: Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA): Bulge-disk decomposition of KiDS and VIKING data in the nearby universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10077v1.summary: This thesis presents a catalogue of robust structural parameters for the components of nearby GAMA galaxies. The sample consists of 13096 galaxies at redshifts z < 0.08 with imaging data from the Kilo-Degree Survey and VISTA INfrared Galaxy survey. We fit three models to the surface brightness distribution of each galaxy in each band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16532v2.title: Merger Signatures are Common, but not Universal, In Massive, Recently-Quenched Galaxies at z~0.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16532v2.summary: We present visual classifications of merger-induced tidal disturbances in 143 post-starburst galaxies at z$\sim$0.7identified. This sample spectroscopicallyselects galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey that have stopped their primary epoch of star formation within the past $500 Myrs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10013v1.title: Star-formation rate and stellar mass calibrations based on infrared photometry and their dependence on stellar population age and extinction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10013v1.summary: The stellar mass ($M_\star$) and the star-formation rate (SFR) are among the most important features that characterize galaxies. Measuring these fundamentalproperties accurately is critical for understanding the present state of galaxies. This work explores the dependence of the IRemission of galaxies on their extinction, and the age of their stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09926v1.title: StarHorse results for spectroscopic surveys + Gaia DR3: Chrono-chemical populations in the solar vicinity, the genuine thick disk, and young-alpha rich stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09926v1.summary: The Gaia mission has provided an invaluable wealth of astrometric data for more than a billion stars in our Galaxy. Using the Bayesian isochrone-fitting code StarHorse, we derive distances and extinctions for 10 million unique stars observed by Gaia. We identify three distinct groups in all three samples. Theirkinematic properties confirm them to be the genuine chemical thick disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11196v2.title: The XXL Survey L. Active galactic nucleus contamination in galaxy clusters: Detection and cosmological impact
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11196v2.summary: X-ray observations of galaxy clusters are impacted by the presence of active galaxies (AGNs) in a manner that is challenging to quantify. The majority of these systems are otherwise missed by current X-ray cluster-detection methods. We introduce a new automated class for AGN-contaminated (AC)centricclusters in the XXL source detection pipeline.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17507v2.title: The effects of Time-Variable Absorption due to Gamma-Ray Bursts In Active Galactic Nuclei Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17507v2.summary: Both long and short gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are expected to occur in the dense environments of active galactic nuclei (AGN) accretion disks. As these bursts propagate through the disks they live in, they photoionize the medium causing time-dependent opacity that results in transients with unique spectral evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00604v2.title: Tidal Stripping in the Adiabatic Limit
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00604v2.summary: We present a model for the remnants of haloes that have gone through anadiabatic tidal stripping process. We show that this model exactly reproducesthe remnant of an NFW halo that is exposed to a slowly increasing isotropictidal field and approximately for an anisotropic tidal field. The model can be used to predict the asymptotic mass loss limit for orbiting subhaloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09883v1.title: On the propagation of Alfvén waves in the dusty interstellar medium. Can we neglect dust inertia in molecular clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09883v1.summary: Alfv\'en waves are fundamental magnetized modes which play an important role in the dynamics of magnetized flows such as the interstellar medium (ISM) Yet, in most calculations, for numerical reasons, the grain inertia is usually neglected. We investigate analytically the propagation of Alfv \'en waves both in a single-size and multi-size grain medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08103v2.title: The need for obscured supermassive black hole growth to explain quasar proximity zones in the epoch of reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08103v2.summary: Proximity zones of high-redshift quasars are unique probes of supermassive black hole formation. But explaining proximity zone sizes and black hole masses has proved to be challenging. We show that small proximity zones can be readilyexplained by quasARS that vary in brightness with a short duty cycle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09845v1.title: The `blazar sequence' in TeV band
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09845v1.summary: The `blazar sequence' has been proposed for more than 20 years, yet itsnature is still unclear. In this work, for the first time, we expand this topic to the TeV band by using a sample of 58 TeV blazars. We find the blazar sequence is shown in the flaring state rather than in the quiescent state.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v1.title: WIYN Open Cluster Study 89. M48 (NGC 2548) 2: Lithium Abundances in the 420 Myr Open Cluster M48 From Giants Through K Dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v1.summary: Li-Teff trends of the Li Dip (6675-6200K), Li Plateau (6200-6000K), and G and K dwarfs (6000-4000K) are very clearly delineated. Early F dwarfs already show evidence of Li depletion seen in older clusters. Forlate-G/K dwarfs, faster rotators show higher Li than slower rotators.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v1.title: The Emergence of Brightest Cluster Galaxy in the Most Massive Protocluster Core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v1.summary: A pair of massive quiescent galaxies are likely in the process of merging at the centre of the spectroscopicallyconfirmed, extremely massive protocluster BOSS1244. The galaxies were detected with HubbleSpace Telescope (HST) grism slitless spectroscopic observations. These two galaxies are among the brightest member galaxies in the cluster and are separated by about 70 physicalkiloparsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09712v1.title: A catalog of nearby accelerating star candidates in Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09712v1.summary: New catalog of accelerating star candidates with Gaia. Designated as Gaia Nearby AcceleratingStar Catalog (GNASC) It contains 29,684 members identified using a supervisedmachine-learning algorithm. Test data suggest catalog members each have a 68% likelihood of true astrometric accelerating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09637v1.title: Origin of the diffuse 4-8 keV emission in M82
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09637v1.summary: X-ray spectroscopic study of the 4-8 keV diffuse emission found in the central part of the nearby starburst galaxy. The Fexxv emission at 6.7 keV is enhanced only in a limited area close to the starburst disc. This shows the presence of non-thermal emission due to inverse Compton scattering.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08336v2.title: CMR exploration I -- filament structure with synthetic observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08336v2.summary: We explore the collision-induced magnetic reconnection (CMR) mechanism that forms filamentarymolecular clouds. Athena++ is used to model CMR in the context of resistive magnetohydrodynamics. We quantify the results with five metrics, including the density probability and dominant fiber width. Overall, the exploration provides useful initial insights to the CMR mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02675v2.title: Symphony: Cosmological Zoom-in Simulation Suites over Four Decades of Host Halo Mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02675v2.summary: We present Symphony, a compilation of $262$ cosmological, cold-dark-matter-only zoom-in simulations spanning four decades of host halomass. The highest-resolution regions in these simulations are resolved with a dark matter particle mass of 3 times host virial mass. We demonstrate that these predictions successfully resolve the formation histories of the halos that host nearly all currentlyobservable satellite galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09583v1.title: Can we observe the ion-neutral drift velocity in prestellar cores?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09583v1.summary: Ambipolar diffusion is thought to be an integral process in star formation. The ion-neutral drift velocity is inherently very small. The coldest modelled cores exhibited drift velocities comparable to the sound speed. In idealized scenarios, the drift velocity survives radiative transfer effects and can in principle be observed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09574v1.title: 3D Radiative Transfer Modelling and Virial Analysis of Starless Cores in the B10 Region of the Taurus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09574v1.summary: New observations at 1.2mm and 2.0mm with the NIKA2 instrument on the IRAM 30m have probed theinner regions of 14 low-mass starless cores. We find 9 out of the 14 cores ($64\%$) are either in virialophobicequilibrium or are bound by gravity and external pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09570v1.title: CLEAR: Survey Overview, Data Analysis and Products
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09570v1.summary: We present an overview of the CANDELS Lyman-a Emission At Reionization(CLEAR) survey. CLEAR is a 130 orbit program of the Hubble Space Telescope using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) IR G102 grism. In this Paper, we describe the CLEAR survey, the survey strategy, the data acquisition, reduction, and processing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09568v1.title: RXJ0437+00: Constraining Dark Matter with Exotic Gravitational Lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09568v1.summary: The galaxies lensed by RXJ0437 are magnified by factors ranging from 30 to 300. The H-U images are located only 20 -- 50 kpc from the galaxy cluster's centre. These systems are able to constrain the inner slope of the mass distribution. They can be used to probe for small-scale ($\sim 10^{9} M_\odot}$substructures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v1.title: Multimessenger study of merging massive black holes in the Obelisk simulation: gravitational waves, electromagnetic counterparts, and their link to galaxy and black hole populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v1.summary: Massive black hole (BH) mergers are predicted to be powerful sources of low-frequency gravitational waves (GWs) Coupling the detection of GWs withelectromagnetic (EM) detection can provide key information about merging BHs and their environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01345v2.title: The MUSE Ultra Deep Field (MUDF). III. Hubble Space Telescope WFC3 Grism Spectroscopy and Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01345v2.summary: We present extremely deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) observations of the MUSE Ultra Deep Field (MUDF) This unique region of the sky contains two quasars at $z \approx$ 3.22 that are separated by only 500 kpc. We have obtained 90 orbits of HST WFC3 G141 near-infrared grism spectroscopy of this field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13708v2.title: How baryons affect halos and large-scale structure: a unified picture from the Simba simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13708v2.summary: The main physical drivers shaping the distribution of matter at all scales are star formation-driven galacticoutflows and AGN jets. 87% of the baryonic mass in the Universe lies in the IGM at $z=0$, with 67% being in the form of warm-hot IGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09473v1.title: Molecular gas in super spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09473v1.summary: Only a small fraction of galaxies are disk-like and actively star-forming objects. These so-called 'super spirals' are ideal objects to better understand how galaxy evolution proceeds. We analyze their molecular gas mass in relation to their star formation rate (SFR) and stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09425v1.title: Velocity measurement in the extensive [OIII] emission region 1.2° south-east of M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09425v1.summary: The discovery of a broad, $\sim$1.5$^{\circ}$ long filamentary [OIII] 5007emission south-east of the M31 nucleus has recently beenreported. More than 100 hours of exposures of a wide field have allowed this pioneering detection based on 30 narrow-band filters and several small refractors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09391v1.title: Rapidly growing primordial black holes as seeds of the massive high-redshift JWST Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09391v1.summary: A group of massive galaxies at redshifts of $z\geq 6.5$ have been recently discovered by James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) The formation of some primordial black holes (PBHs) formed in the early Universe via super-Eddington accretion within the dark matter halo can explain these observations. These PBHs may act as seeds for early galaxies formation with masses of $\sim 10^{9}-10^{10}~M_\odot$ at redshift 8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09374v1.title: Extinction towards the cluster R136 in the Large Magellanic Cloud: An extinction law from the near-infrared to the ultraviolet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09374v1.summary: The cluster R136 in the giant star-forming region 30 Doradus in the Large                Magellanic Cloud (LMC) offers a unique opportunity to resolve a stellarpopulation in a starburst-like environment. We obtain the near-infrared to ultraviolet extinction towards 50 stars in the core of R136, employing the 'extinction without standards' method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09371v1.title: MIGHTEE-\HI: Possible interactions with the galaxy NGC~895
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09371v1.summary: The galaxy NGC~895 was previously thought to be isolated. High-sensitivity observations from the MeerKAT large survey project MIGHTEE reveal possible interactions. NGC 895 is an actively star-forming galaxy with a SFR of 1.75.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02822v2.title: An empirical approach to selecting the first growing black hole seeds with JWST/NIRCam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02822v2.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) will have the sensitivity to detect early low-mass black holes. Based on the JAGUAR mock catalog of galaxies, we present a clean color selection that takes advantage of the unique UV slope of accreting supermassive black holes with relatively low mass and high accretion rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12978v3.title: On the gravitational lensing interpretation of three gravitational wave detections in the mass gap by LIGO and Virgo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12978v3.summary: Gravitational lensing delays the arrival of gravitational waves, and alters their amplitude. This would provide a physically well-understoodinterpretation of GW detections in the ''mass gap'' between neutron stars and black holes. LIGO-Virgo's third run found three GWs that may have been affected by gravitational lensing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v1.title: Exploring dark matter spike distribution around the Galactic centre with stellar orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v1.summary: Precise measurements of the stellar orbits around Sagittarius A* have established the existence of a supermassive black hole (SMBH) at the Galactic center. Due to the interplay between the SMBH and dark matter, the DMdensity profile in the innermost region of the Galaxy is still an open question. We examine the radius and slope of the generalized NFW spike profile, analyze the Einasto spike, and discuss the influence of DM annihilation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09947v2.title: High-resolution Imaging of Two Radio Quasars at the End of the Reionization Epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09947v2.summary: There are approximately 250 quasars discovered at redshift $z\geq6$, of which only a handful were detected in radio bands. Even fewer were imaged with the highest resolution very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) technique. Our VLBAobservations revealed a flat-spectrum compact radio source. The latter has an UV/optical spectrum characteristic of BL Lacobjects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09263v1.title: Radio and mid-infrared properties of the blazar J1419$-$0838
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09263v1.summary: The radio quasar NVSS J141922$-$083830 was initiallyclassified as an uncategorised blazar-type object. Later, using observations and modeling, its was found to be a flat-spectrumradio quasar (FSRQ) Its radio emission has never been discussed in sufficientlydepth in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09259v1.title: The Origin of the Large Magellanic Cloud Globular Cluster NGC 2005
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09259v1.summary: The ancient Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) globular cluster NGC 2005 has reportedly been reported to have an ex-situ origin. The LMC could have partially formed from smaller merged dwarf galaxies. The present analysis points to the need for further development of numerical simulations and observational indices.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08795v2.title: Rapidly evolving Galactic plane outbursts in NEOWISE: Revisiting the Galactic nova rate with the first all-sky search in the mid-infrared
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08795v2.summary: The Galactic nova rate is intimately linked to our understanding of its chemical enrichment and progenitor channels of Type Ia supernovae. Pastestimates have varied by more than an order of magnitude. Using 8 years of data from the NEOWISE mid-infrared survey, we identify 49 candidate Galactic novae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09246v1.title: Correlation analysis between several observables of OJ 287 radio jet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09246v1.summary: We collected the archival data of blazar OJ~287 from heterogeneous very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) monitoring programs at 2.3 GHz, 8.6 GHz, 15 GHz and 43 GHz. We employ the cross-correlation function to search the correlations and the Monte Carlo technique to verify the certainty of correlations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12689v2.title: Theory and phenomenology of stressed wave-dark-matter soliton
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12689v2.summary: Soliton in the hostile turbulent wave dark matter ($\Psi$DM) halo of a galaxy                agitates with various kinds of excitation. Soliton breathing at amplitudes on the verge of breakup is also a highlight of this work. The mock solution, constructed from the simulation data, sheds lights on the dynamics of the large-amplitude breathing soliton.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09129v1.title: The parallax and 3D kinematics of water masers in the massive star-forming region G034.43+0.24
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09129v1.summary: The water masers display arc-like distributions, possibly bow shocks, associated with winds from one or more massive young stars. The measured 3-dimensional motion of G034.43+0.24 indicates a near-circular Galactic orbit. This locates the water maser near the inner edge of the Sagittarius spiral arm and at one end of a linear distribution of massiveyoung stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09049v1.title: On the 3D Curvature and Dynamics of the Musca filament
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09049v1.summary: Filaments are ubiquitous in the interstellar medium (ISM), yet theirformation and evolution remains the topic of intense debate. In order to obtain a more comprehensive view of the 3D morphology and evolution of the Muscafilament, we model the C$^{18}$O(2-1) emission along the filament crest with several large-scale velocity field structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07238v2.title: ALMA-IMF. V. Prestellar and protostellar core populations in the W43 cloud complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07238v2.summary: Recent observations in the W43 molecular complex of top-heavy CMFs raise questions about our understanding of the starformation processes and their evolution in space and time. Protostellar cores are found to be, on average, moremassive and smaller in size than prestellar cores. Our results could be explained by clump-fed models in which cores grow in mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v1.title: Overall Binary Evolution Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v1.summary: Accreting compact objects are crucial to understand several importantastrophysical phenomena. We still do not fully understand how they form and evolve. This chapter will review the current theoretical status of our knowledge of these objects. It will discuss standing problems and potential solutions to these problems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v1.title: First results from the JWST Early Release Science Program Q3D: The Warm Ionized Gas Outflow in z ~ 1.6 Quasar XID 2028 and its Impact on the Host Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v1.summary: Quasar feedback may regulate the growth of supermassive black holes, quench                coeval star formation, and impact galaxy morphology. However, direct evidence for quasar feedback in action at the epoch of peak black hole accretion at z ~ 2 remains elusive. A good case in point is the 1.6 quasar WISEA J100211.29+013706.7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08919v1.title: Short-lived Radionuclides in the Milky Way Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08919v1.summary: Short-lived radionuclides (SLRs) have a half-life $leq$ 100 Myr. We have developed GalacticChemical Evolution (GCE) models for SLRs. These models predict the temporal andspatial evolution of SLR abundance trends in the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v1.title: A CEERS Discovery of an Accreting Supermassive Black Hole 570 Myr after the Big Bang: Identifying a Progenitor of Massive z > 6 Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v1.summary: We report the discovery of an accreting supermassive black hole at z=8.679, in CEERS_1019. We detect a significant broad (FWHM~1200 km/s) component in the H$\beta$ emission line, which we conclude originates in the broad-line region of an active galacticucleus (AGN) The mass of the black hole is $6.95 (-0.5) x the Eddington limit. We use this presently highest-redshift AGN discovery to place constraints on black hole seeding models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15689v2.title: VINTERGATAN-GM: The cosmological imprints of early mergers on Milky-Way-mass galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15689v2.summary: We present a new suite of cosmological zoom-in hydrodynamical simulations of Milky-Way mass galaxies. We study how a varying mass ratio for a Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE) progenitorimpacts the chemodynamics of halo stars. We find markedly different morphologies at $z=0$ following a growing merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16320v3.title: Colliding Ghosts: Constraining Inflation with the Parity-Odd Galaxy Four-Point Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16320v3.summary: Within canonical models of inflation, no parity-asymmetry can occur. But breaking of the standard assumptions can lead to parity violation within the Effective Field Theory of Inflation. This is also the first time Cosmological Collider signatures have directly been searched for in observational data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08860v1.title: The Nature of LoBAL QSOs: II. HST/WFC3 Observations Reveal Host Galaxies Dominated by Mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08860v1.summary: Low-ionization Broad Absorption Line QSOs (LoBALs) are suspected to be merging systems in which extreme, AGN-driven outflows have been triggered. We present the first high-resolution morphological analysis of a volume-limited sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08849v1.title: Electron-Ion Temperature Ratio in Astrophysical Shocks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08849v1.summary: Collisionless shock waves in supernova remnants and the solar wind heat electrons less effectively than they heat ions. The values of T$_e$/T$_p$ inferred from the H alphaprofiles of supernova remnant shocks behave differently as a function of Machnumber or Alfv\'{e}n Mach number.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08846v1.title: On the Dynamical Heating of Dwarf Galaxies in a Fuzzy Dark Matter Halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08846v1.summary: Fuzzy Dark Matter (FDM), consisting of ultralight bosons, is an intriguing alternative to Cold Dark Matter. FDMhalos consist of a central solitonic core surrounded by a large envelope of excited states. Wave interference gives rise to order unity density fluctuations throughout the envelope. The resulting gravitational potential perturbations are an efficient source of dynamicalheating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08842v1.title: Multiwavelength monitoring of the nucleus in PBC J2333.9-2343: the giant radio galaxy with a blazar-like core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08842v1.summary: PBC J2333.9-2343 is a giant radio galaxy at z = 0.047 with a bright central core associated to a blazar nucleus. Large flux increases are observed on timescales shorter than a month, which are interpreted as flaring events.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08838v1.title: Surviving the Waves: evidence for a Dark Matter cusp in the tidally disrupting Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08838v1.summary: We use spectroscopic data for Red Giant Branch (RGB) stars in the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) to build a mass model of the SMC. We then apply our method to real SMC data, finding that the stars of the cleaned sample are isotropic at all radii. We provide a new, analytic,density profile that reproduces Dark Matter heating behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08841v1.title: X-HESS: a large sample of highly accreting serendipitous AGN under the XMM-Newton microscope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08841v1.summary: The bulk of X-ray spectroscopic studies of active galactic nuclei (AGN) arefocused on local ($z < 0.1$) sources with low-to-moderate ($< 0.3$) Eddingtonratio. In this work we present the preliminary results from the analysis of a sample of radio-quiet AGN at $0.06 \leq z \leap 3.3$, based on the 10th release of the XMM-Newton serendipitous source catalogue.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08833v1.title: Feedback in the merging galaxy group NGC6338
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08833v1.summary: The galaxy group NGC6338 is one of the most violent group-group mergers known to date. While the central dominant galaxies rush at each other at 1400km/s along the line of sight, the central gas in the BCGs remains cool. There are also indications ofipientfeedback from active galactic nuclei (AGNs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08827v1.title: Simulations of pre-supernova feedback in spherical clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08827v1.summary: We present a one-dimensional radiation-hydrodynamic model of a sphericallysymmetric cloud evolving under the influence of the self-gravity and the feedback from a star cluster forming in its centre. The model is compared to the semi-analytic codeWARPFIELD implementing similar physical processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08831v1.title: VISIONS: The VISTA Star Formation Atlas -- I. Survey overview
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08831v1.summary: VISIONS is an ESO public survey of five nearby star-forming cloud complexes. It was designed to build aninfrared legacy archive similar to that of 2MASS. The observations yielded approximately 1.15 million images, which comprise 19 TB of raw data. VISIONS will enable addressing a range of topics, including the 3D distribution and motion of embedded stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08813v1.title: A High Fraction of Heavily X-ray Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08813v1.summary: We present new estimates on the fraction of heavily X-ray obscured, Compton-thick (CT) active galactic nuclei (AGNs) out to a redshift of $z \leq$0.8. From a sample of 540 AGNs selected by mid-IR (MIR) properties in observedX-ray survey fields, we forward model the observed-to-intrinsic X-rays ratio. Our results suggests at least 50% of all MIR-selectedAGNs, possibly more.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08793v1.title: Modelling of the multi-transition periodic flaring in G9.62+0.20E
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08793v1.summary: We present detailed modeling of periodic flaring events in the G9.62+0.20E star-forming region. Our analysis is performed within the framework of the one-dimensional Maxwell-Bloch equations. We find that the variations in flaring time-scales are manifestations of and are best modeled with Dicke's superradiance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12069v1.title: Machine Learning the Tip of the Red Giant Branch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12069v1.summary: A novel method for investigating the sensitivity of the tip of the red giant branch (TRGB) I band magnitude $M_I$ to stellar input physics is presented. We create a grid of theoretical stellar models with varying mass,initial helium abundance, and initial metallicity, and train a machine learningemulator to predict $M-I$ as a function of these parameters. We find that our emulator enables a direct comparison of theoretical predictions with empirical calibrations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12033v1.title: The interplay between radio AGN activity and their host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12033v1.summary: This is the first study to look at the impact of radio jets on the galaxy. The study also looks at the effect of radio waves on the formation of new stars. The authors conclude that the radio activity in the galaxy is likely to have a major impact on the growth of new galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12011v1.title: The chemistry of H2NC in the interstellar medium and the role of the C + NH3 reaction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12011v1.summary: We carried out an observational search for the recently discovered molecule H2NC, and its more stable isomer H2CN, toward eight cold dense clouds (L1544, L134N, TMC-2, Lupus-1A, L1489, T MC-1 NH3, L 1498, and L1641N) and two diffuse clouds (B0415+379 and B0355+508) The column densities for both H2 NC and H2 CN are in the range 1e11-1e12 cm-2 and the column density of H2

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11961v1.title: Accurate dust temperature and star formation rate in the most luminous $z>6$ quasar in the HYPerluminous quasars at the Epoch of ReionizatION (HYPERION) sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11961v1.summary: We present ALMA Band 9 continuum observation of the ultraluminousquasi-stellar object (QSO) SDSS J0100+2802. We find that the SMBH is dominating the process of growth in this QSO at $z=6.327$, when the Universe was $865$ Myr old.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v1.title: JWST/NIRSpec First Census of Broad-Line AGNs at z=4-7: Detection of 10 Faint AGNs with M_BH~10^6-10^7 M_sun and Their Host Galaxy Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v1.summary: We present a first statistical sample of faint type-1 AGNs at $z>4$identified by JWST/NIRSpec deep spectroscopy. The AGNs have low-mass black holes with remarkably lower than those of low-luminosity quasars previously identified with ground-based telescopes. Such faint AGNs contribute to cosmicipientreionization, while the total contribution is not large because of their faint nature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11877v1.title: Dynamic and polarimetric VLBI imaging with a multiscalar approach
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11877v1.summary: Multiscale imaging approaches such as DoG-HiT were developed to alleviate the VLBI imaging problem and showed a promising performance. We extend the multiscalar imagingapproach to polarimetric imaging, reconstructions of dynamically evolving sources and dynamic reconstructions. The approach is relatively lightweight, fast and data driven.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00524v2.title: Studying the prestellar core L1517B in Taurus molecular cloud using ammonia (NH_{3}) observation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00524v2.summary: Prestellar core L1517B is close to round in shape with a constant internal kinetic temperature of 9K. The core seems to be an isothermal sphere. A constant level of turbulence persists in the core, which is subsonic in nature. The work demonstrates the capability of studying the internal structures of prestellar cores withinterferometric telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11799v1.title: Investigation of a small X-ray flaring event in NLS1 galaxy NGC 4051
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11799v1.summary: We performed a detailed broadband spectral and timing analysis of a small flaring event of ~120 ks in a narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxy NGC 4051. During the flare, the NuSTAR count rate peaked at 2.5 times the mean count rate before the flare. We found no significant change in the inner accretion disc or the seed photon temperature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11736v1.title: CEERS Key Paper VI: JWST/MIRI Uncovers a Large Population of Obscured AGN at High Redshifts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11736v1.summary: Mid-infrared observations are powerful in identifying heavily obscured ActiveGalactic Nuclei (AGN) which have weak emission in other wavelengths. The Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) onboard JWST offers an excellent chance to perform such studies. We take advantage of the MIRI imaging data from the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11713v1.title: The physics of gravitational waves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11713v1.summary: Lectures on gravitational waves should be appropriate for PhD students or MSc students that have taken a first course in general relativity. The focus is on deriving results from first principles, rather than astrophysical applications. These lecture notes collect the material that I have been using over the years for various short courses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11691v1.title: A versatile classification tool for galactic activity using optical and infrared colors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11691v1.summary: We use the Random Forest (RF) algorithm to develop a tool for automated activity classification of galaxies. We train the algorithm on acombination of mid-IR (WISE) and optical photometric data. Applying it to an all-sky galaxy catalog (HECATE) reveals a largepopulation of low-luminosity AGNs outside the AGN locus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.05104v3.title: Modified gravity over the linearized metric perturbation for two body dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.05104v3.summary: Modified gravity is studied over the linearized metricperturbation in post-Minkowskian theory. This is a different aspect for two body dynamics without taking usual self force originated from the radiative backscattering of gravitational waves. The theoretical result is checked for galactic flat rotation curve and is very good agreement with 249 kilometerper second solar rotational speed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v2.title: The Emergence of Brightest Cluster Galaxy in the Most Massive Protocluster Core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v2.summary: A pair of massive quiescent galaxies are likely in the process of merging at the centre of the spectroscopicallyconfirmed, extremely massive protocluster BOSS1244. The galaxies were detected with HubbleSpace Telescope (HST) grism slitless spectroscopic observations. These two galaxies are among the brightest member galaxies in the cluster and are separated by about 70 physicalkiloparsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11614v1.title: Turbulence in Zeeman Measurements from Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11614v1.summary: Magnetic fields (B-fields) play an important role in molecular cloudfragmentation and star formation, but are very difficult to detect. The correlation between the field strength (B) and gas density (n) of anisolated cloud has been suggested as an indication of the dynamical importance of B-fields relative to self-gravity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v2.title: WIYN Open Cluster Study 89. M48 (NGC 2548) 2: Lithium Abundances in the 420 Myr Open Cluster M48 From Giants Through K Dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v2.summary: We consider WIYN/Hydra spectra of 329 photometric candidate members of the M48 open cluster M48. We report Lithium detections or upper limits for ARTICLE234 members and likely members. The giants are consistent with subgiant Li dilution and priorMS Li depletion due to rotational mixing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11539v1.title: The 300 parsec resolution imaging of a z = 8.31 galaxy: Turbulent ionized gas and potential stellar feedback 600 million years after the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11539v1.summary: ALMA imaging of the [OIII] 88€$\mu$m line and dust continuum emission from a $z = 8.312$ Lyman break galaxy MACS0416_Y1. The cross correlation between dust and ultraviolet-related emission is unity on a galactic scale, while it drops at < 1 kpc. This could be a superbubble producing galactic-scale outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11497v1.title: A Critique of the Spite Plateau, and the Astration of Primordial Lithium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11497v1.summary: We investigate the distribution of the lithium abundances, A(Li), of metal-poor dwarf and subgiant stars within the limits 5500 K < Teff < 6700 K. We address the problem of the several methods that yield Teff differences up to 350 K. Insofar as [Fe/H] increases as the universe ages, the behavior of A( Li) reflects chaotic star formation involving destruction of primordial Li.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11441v1.title: The bar rotation rate as a diagnostic of dark matter content in the centre of disc galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11441v1.summary: NGC4264 and NGC4277 have similar morphologies, sizes, and luminosities. But, N GC4264 hosts a fast bar, which extends to nearly the corotation. The bar embedded in NGC 4277 is slow and falls short of the short ofcorotation. This is the first time that the bar rotation rate is coupled to dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11397v1.title: A JWST/NIRSpec Exploration of the Connection between Ionization Parameter, Electron Density, and Star-Formation-Rate Surface Density in z=2.7-6.3 Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11397v1.summary: We conduct a statistical analysis of the factors responsible for the variation in the ionization parameter (U) of high-redshift star-forming galaxies. The sample consists of 48 galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts z=2.7-6.3. Using composite spectra of galaxies in bins of [OIII]/[OII] (i.e., O32) as a proxy for U, we determine that galaxies with higher O32 have <n_e> ~ 500cm^-3 that are at least a factor of ~5 larger than that of lower-O32

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11393v1.title: Short-lived radioisotope enrichment in star-forming regions from stellar winds and supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11393v1.summary: The abundance of the short-lived radioisotopes 26-Al and 60-Fe in the early tumultuousSolar system is usually explained by the Sun either forming from pre-enriched material, or the Sun's protosolar disc being polluted by a nearby supernova. In this paper, we extend the disc enrichment scenario toinclude the contribution of 26- Al from the winds of massive stars before they explode as supernovae. We find that stellar winds contribute to the Solar system's 26-al/60-Fe ratio in up to 50 per cent of discs in dense star-forming regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02292v2.title: A Trail of the Invisible: Blue Globular Clusters Trace the Radial Density Distribution of the Dark Matter -- Case Study of NGC 4278
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02292v2.summary: NGC 4278 is located in a small loose group. The galaxy lacks fine structure out to a radius of $70 kpc. The red GCsubpopulation traces well the stellar mass density profile from 2.4 out to even 14 half-mass radii. The blue GC subpopulation traces the total massdensity profile over a large radial range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11368v1.title: A Bayesian Approach To The Halo-Galaxy-SMBH Connection Through Cosmic Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11368v1.summary: We study the co-evolution of dark matter halos, galaxies and supermassive black holes using an empirical galaxy evolution model from $z=0$ -- $10$. We demonstrate that by connecting dark matter structure evolution with simpleempirical prescriptions for baryonic processes, we are able to faithfully produce key observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11361v1.title: The Evolution of Compact Symmetric Objects -- A Possible Connection with Tidal Disruption Events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11361v1.summary: Compact Symmetric Objects (CSOs) form a distinct class of jetted activegalactic nuclei (jetted-AGN) There are two unrelated classes: an edge-dimmed, low-luminosity class (CSO 1) and a edge-brightened, high-l luminosity class(CSO 2) We advance the hypothesis that CSO 2.0s are young and evolve through CSO 1.1s into CSO2.2s, which are old.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11360v1.title: The massive relic galaxy NGC 1277 is dark matter deficient. From dynamical models of integral-field stellar kinematics out to five effective radii
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11360v1.summary: According to the $Lambda$CDM cosmology, present-day massive galaxies should contain a sizable fraction of dark matter within their stellar body. The best relic galaxy candidate to date is NGC 1277, in the Perseus cluster. By using Jeans anisotropic models we find a negligent dark matter fraction within $5\,R_{\rm e}$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11357v1.title: Towards a Comprehensive Catalog of Bona Fide Compact Symmetric Objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11357v1.summary: Compact Symmetric Objects (CSOs) are jetted Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) with all projected size < 1 kpc. The classification was introduced to distinguish these objects from the majority of known compact jetted-AGN. Some objects with jet axes close to the line of sight have been mis-classified as CSOs in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11354v1.title: Limits on Dark Matter Annihilation from the Shape of Radio Emission in M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11354v1.summary: We use observations of the Andromeda Galaxy (M31) to construct a model of the gas, magnetic fields, and starlight. We set constraints on dark matter annihilation to $b\bar{b}$ using the morphology of 3.6 cm radio emission. We base our limits on the region between $0.9-6.9$ kpc from the center of M31.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11348v1.title: On the Reionization-Era Globular Cluster in Low-Mass Galaxy Eridanus II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11348v1.summary: Eri II is the lowest-mass galaxy known to host a globular cluster. The GC and Eri II have similar ages and metallicities. Both are reionization-era relics that were formed before the peak of cosmic star and GC formation. Archaeological studies of GCs in nearby low-mass galaxies may be the only way to constrain GC formation in such low- mass systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11349v1.title: An extremely compact, low-mass post-starburst galaxy at $z=5.2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11349v1.summary: We report the discovery of a low-mass $z=5.200\pm 0.002$ galaxy that is in the process of ceasing its star formation. The galaxy, MACS0417-z5PSB, ismultiply imaged with magnification factors $sim40$ by the galaxy cluster MACSJ0417.5-1154. Using spectrophotometric fitting, we find a remarkably lowstellar mass of $z\sim5$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11321v1.title: The ALMA REBELS Survey: The First Infrared Luminosity Function Measurement at $\mathbf{z \sim 7}
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11321v1.summary: We present the first observational infrared luminosity function (IRLF) in the Epoch of Reionization (EoR) based on a UV-selected galaxy sample with ALMA spectroscopic observations. 16 sources exhibit a dust detection, 15 of which are also spectroscopicallyconfirmed through the [CII] line. The inferred obscured contribution to cosmic star-formation rate density at $z\sim7$ amounts to -2.66% of UV-based estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16275v2.title: The THESAN project: Lyman-alpha emitter luminosity function calibration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16275v2.summary: The observability of Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies (LAEs) can provide a sensitive probe of the evolving neutral hydrogen gas distribution. We utilize the new THESAN suite of large-volume (95.5 cMpc) cosmological radiation-hydrodynamic simulations to directly model the Ly$\alpha$ emission from individual galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16881v1.title: Systematic KMTNet Planetary Anomaly Search. IX. Complete Sample of 2016 Prime-Field Planets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16881v1.summary: Five new planets were found by searching $2016$KMTNet prime fields. The ultimate goal of this series is to build a complete planet sample. These $buried$ planets show a wide range of masses from Earth--class to Super--Jupiter--class, and are located in both the disk and thebulge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08413v2.title: ALMA Observation of a $z\gtrsim10$ Galaxy Candidate Discovered with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08413v2.summary: ALMA observation of a $z\gtrsim10$ galaxy candidate (GHZ1) from the GLASS-JWST Early Release Science Program. No line or continuum is clearly detected, with a 5$\sigma$ upper limit of the continuum flux. The inferred star formation rate of GHZ1 is consistent with the properties of the low metallicity dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.06969v4.title: Public data release of the FIRE-2 cosmological zoom-in simulations of galaxy formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.06969v4.summary: FIRE-2 simulations achieve parsec-scale resolution to explicitly model the multi-phase interstellar medium. We release complete snapshots from 3 suites of simulations. Snapshots include all stored properties for all worrisomedark matter, gas, and star particles. We describe publicly available python packages for reading and analyzing these simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16849v1.title: Dwarf Galaxy Discoveries from the KMTNet Supernova Program III. the Milky-Way Analog NGC~2997 Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16849v1.summary: We present the discovery of 48 new and the analysis of 55, including 7 previously discovered, dwarf galaxy candidates around the giant spiral galaxy NGC~2997. Their surface brightness and total absolute magnitudes range between 20.3--26.7 mag arcsec$^{-2}$ and --(8.02--17.69) mag, respectively.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16826v1.title: Galaxy interactions in filaments and sheets: insights from EAGLE simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16826v1.summary: We study the colour and star formation rates of paired galaxies in filaments and sheets using the EAGLE simulations. We find that the major pairs with pair.separation $<50$ kpc are bluer and more star forming in. filamentaryenvironments compared to those hosted in sheet-like environments. We propose that the enhancement of star formation rate at smaller pair separation in filamentary environments is caused by the alignment of galaxy pairs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14073v2.title: Blending from binarity in microlensing searches towards the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14073v2.summary: Studies of gravitational microlensing effects require the estimation of their detection efficiency. This is particularly important for setting limits on the contribution of massive compact objects to the Galactic halo. We use the Gaia catalog of nearby stars to constrain the local binarityrate, which we extrapolate to the distance of the LMC. Then, we estimate themaximum fraction of the cases for which a microlensed event could be significantly modified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15511v2.title: Massive binary black holes from Population II and III stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15511v2.summary: Population III stars, born from the primordial gas in the Universe, lose anegligible fraction of their mass via stellar winds and possibly follow a top-heavy mass function. They have often been regarded as the idealprogenitors of massive black holes. Here, we evolve a large set of Population III binary stars with our population-synthesis code SEVN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v1.title: Pitfalls in applying gravitomagnetism to galactic rotation curve modelling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v1.summary: The flatness of galaxy rotation curves at large radii is generally considered to be a significant piece of evidence in support of the existence of dark matter. Several studies have claimed that post-Newtonian corrections to the equations of galaxy dynamics remove the need for dark matter, but these studies have identified errors in their reasoning.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15515v2.title: Binary black hole mergers from Population III stars: uncertainties from star formation and binary star properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15515v2.summary: Population III (Pop. III) binary stars likely produced the first stellar-born worrisomebinary black hole (BBH) mergers in the Universe. Here, we quantify the main sources of uncertainty for the merger rate density evolution and mass spectrum of Pop. III BBHs by considering four different formation histories. The uncertainty on the orbital properties affects the BBH merger ratedensity by up to two orders of magnitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14016v2.title: The GALAH survey: New diffuse interstellar bands found in residuals of 872,000 stellar spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14016v2.summary: We use more than 872,000 mid-to-high resolution (R $ 20,000) spectra from the GALAH survey to discern the spectra of diffuse interstellarbands (DIBs) We combine the 33,115 best ISM spectra into six reddening bins with a range of $0.1 to $7.7. The majority ofcertain DIBs show a significant excess of equivalent width when compared to reddening.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16658v1.title: SPARC HSBs, and LSBs, the surface density of dark matter haloes, and MOND
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16658v1.summary: In this paper, we use SPARC's HSBs, and LSBs galaxies to verify two issues. The first one is related to one claim of D09, namely: is the DMsurface density (DMsd) a constant universal quantity? The second one is based on a MOND prediction that forHSBs the DMsd is constant, and equal to 2.14.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02631v3.title: Gravitational polarization of test-mass potential in the self-gravitating isothermal gases and a relation with gravitational instability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02631v3.summary: Gravitational polarization in the infiniteisothermal sheet, cylinder, and sphere. The isothermal sheet and cylinder amplify gravitationalfields due to test sheet and line masses by 68 % and 53 % maximally. In the isothermal sphere, gravitational fields due totest point mass areamplified oscillatorily with radius and show a repulsive effect at large radii.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01081v2.title: Coalescing black hole binaries from globular clusters: mass distributions and comparison to gravitational wave data from GWTC-3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01081v2.summary: We use our cluster population model, cBHBd, to explore the mass distribution of merging black hole binaries. We find that none of our models can produce the peak at $m_1\simeq 10M_\odot$ in the primary black hole mass distribution. This disfavours a scenario where most of the sources are formed in globular clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16553v1.title: Dynamics of Binary System around Supermassive Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16553v1.summary: We discuss motion of a binary system around a supermassive black hole. Using Fermi-Walker transport, we construct a local inertial reference frame and set up a Newtonian binary system. We show that there appears the Kozai-Lidov (KL) oscillations when a binary is compact.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16497v1.title: He abundance of Dense Circumstellar Clumps in the Cassiopeia A Supernova Remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16497v1.summary: We report on the result of He abundance analysis of dense circumstellarclumps in the young supernova remnant Cassiopeia A. These clumps are known from previous opticalstudies to be enriched in He along with N. We discuss the mass-loss history of the progenitor star and theorigin of QSFs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16446v1.title: Understanding the chemical evolution of blue Edge-on Low Surface Brightness Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16446v1.summary: ELSBGs show a flatter trend in the mass-metallicity ($M_*-Z$)relation, suggesting that the oxygen abundance enhancement is inefficient. We focused on 77 ELSBGs with HI data and found the closed-box model can not explain their gas fraction and metallicity relation, implying that infall and/oroutflow is needed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16439v1.title: NGC 6302: The Tempestuous Life of a Butterfly
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16439v1.summary: NGC 6302 (The ''Butterfly Nebula'') is an extremely energetic bipolar nebula. Its central star is among the most massive, hottest, and presumably rapidly evolving of all central stars of planetary nebulae. The structure and dynamics of the Butterfly Nebula suggests that its central engine has had a remarkable history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15531v2.title: Eccentricity dynamics of wide binaries -- I. The effect of Galactic tides
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15531v2.summary: A major puzzle concerning the wide stellar binaries in the Solar neighborhood is the origin of their observed superthermal eccentricity. Hamilton (2022) demonstrated that Galactic tides alone cannotproduce a superther mal eccentricity DF from an initially isotropic, non-superthermal one. In this paper we prove that H22's conclusions are in fact valid at all times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16383v1.title: The jet apparent motion and central engine study of Fermi blazars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16383v1.summary: The study of blazar jet has been performed for several decades via the VLBItechnique. The correlation suggests that the apparent motion of the knot is related to the jet power. We found a positive correlation between jet/accretion disk properties and the luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16375v1.title: The large-scale structure of globular clusters in the NGC 1052 group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16375v1.summary: The NGC 1052 group hosts two dark matter-free galaxies with overluminous andmonochromatic globular cluster (GC) systems. We recover two GC density maps, one based on universal photometric properties of GCs from simple stellar population models. We conclude that the GC distribution in the group does not strongly support any formation scenario in particular.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16360v1.title: Multi-phase gas nature in the sub-pc region of the active galactic nuclei II: Optical-UV spectra originated in the ionized gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16360v1.summary: We investigate the spectral properties of ionized gas irradiated by an active galactic nucleus with a supermassive black hole of 10^7 Msun. We show that we can reproduce various broad emission lines in optical and ultraviolet wavelengths. Our results suggest that some properties of the bright UV-optical emission lines observed in Seyfert-like AGNs can be caused by the radiation-driven fountain flow inside the dust sublimation radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16357v1.title: Iron-rich Metal-poor Stars and the Astrophysics of Thermonuclear Events Observationally Classified as Type Ia Supernovae. I. Establishing the Connection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16357v1.summary: The progenitor systems and explosion mechanisms responsible for the Type Ia supernovae are difficult to uniquely constrain using traditional observations. We usepublished theoretical nucleosynthetic yields to identify a set of elementalabundance ratios infrequently observed in metal-poor stars but shared across a range of progenitors. We label stars with this abundance signature ``iron-rich metal- poor'' or IRMP stars. If our interpretation of IRMP star is accurate, then they should be very rare in globular clusters and more common in the Magellanic Clouds and spheroidal galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01218v2.title: Unraveling Twisty Linear Polarization Morphologies in Black Hole Images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01218v2.summary: We investigate general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations (GRMHD) to determine the physical origin of the twisty patterns of linear polarization seen in black hole images. By studying an analytic ring model, we find that the roles of Doppler boosting and lensing aresubdominant. Faraday rotation may cause a systematic shift in the linear polarization pattern.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16257v1.title: FAUST VIII. The protostellar disk of VLA 1623-2417 W and its streamers imaged by ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16257v1.summary: More than 50% of solar-mass stars form in multiple systems. We report observations of the VLA 1623-2417 protostellar system at 50 au angularresolution as part of the ALMA Large Program FAUST. We estimate the dynamical mass of VLA1623W and the mass of its disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16234v1.title: Probing the Star Formation Main Sequence down to $10^{8}$ M$_\odot$ at $1.0<z<3.0$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16234v1.summary: A sample of 34,061 newly-discovered galaxies at $1<z<3$ detected in the GOODS-N field. Virtually these galaxies are not contained in previous public catalogs, effectively doubling the number of known sources in the field. Nearly 60% of our sample presents stellar masses in the range $10^{6-8}$ M$_\odot$ between $1-1.9.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16232v1.title: Global dynamic scaling relations of HI-rich ultra-diffuse galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16232v1.summary: The baryonic Tully-Fisher relation (BTFR) has been validated across a wide range of galaxies. We found that high-velocity galaxies deviated from the BTFR, in line with that reported in the literature. Our result indicates that a high-gas Percentage may play an important role in explaining the deviation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16228v1.title: Disk flaring with TNG50: diversity across Milky Way and M31 analogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16228v1.summary: We use the sample of 198 Milky Way (MW) and Andromeda (M31) analogs from                TNG50 to quantify the level of disk flaring predicted by a modern cosmological hydrodynamical simulation. The typical MW/M31 analogs exhibit disk scaleheights that are $1.5-2$ times larger in the outer region of the disk for both old and young stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16224v1.title: Wide binary stars formed in the turbulent interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16224v1.summary: The interstellar turbulence regulates star formation. We find that wide binaries at a given initial separating point generally exhibit a superthermal $p(e)$. This provides a natural Explanation for the observed superther mal $p (e)$ of the wide binaries in theSolar neighborhood.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16225v1.title: Deciphering Lyman-$α$ Emission Deep into the Epoch of Reionisation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16225v1.summary: One of the brightest emission lines in star-forming galaxies, Lyman-$\alpha$ was predicted to emerge only towards the end of the epoch of reionisation, about one billion years after the Big Bang. This picture has been challenged over the past decade by the surprising detection of Ly-$\ alpha$ in galaxies less than 500 million years old.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16226v1.title: Forming intracluster gas in a galaxy protocluster at a redshift of 2.16
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16226v1.summary: Direct observations of the intracluster gas have been limited only to mature clusters in the latter three-quarters of the Universe. This result indicates the presence of a nascent ICM within the Spiderweb protocluster at redshift $z=2.156$, around 10 billion years ago. The SZ effect is lower than expected from dynamical considerations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16227v1.title: The ALMA-ALPAKA survey I: high-resolution CO and [CI] kinematics of star-forming galaxies at z = 0.5-3.5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16227v1.summary: Spatially-resolved studies of the kinematics of galaxies provide crucial insights into their assembly and evolution. We present ALPAKA, a projectaimed at gathering high-resolution observations of CO and [CI] emission lines of star-forming galaxies at z=0.5-3.5 from the ALMA public archive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05066v2.title: The undiscovered ultra-diffuse galaxies of the Local Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05066v2.summary: Ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) are attractive candidates to probe cosmological models and test theories of galaxy formation at low masses. They are difficult to detect because of their low surface brightness. In the Local Group only a handful of UDGs have been found to date.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16215v1.title: The Circumgalactic Medium of Milky Way-like Galaxies in the TNG50 Simulation -- II: Cold, Dense Gas Clouds and High-Velocity Cloud Analogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16215v1.summary: We use the TNG50 simulation of the IllustrisTNG project to study cold, denseClouds of gas in the circumgalactic media (CGM) of Milky Way-like galaxies. We find that their CGM is typically filled with of order one hundred (thousand)reasonably (marginally) resolved clouds. There is a large variation in cloud abundance from galaxy to galaxy, and the physical properties of clouds are also diverse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16217v1.title: Milky Way and Andromeda analogs from the TNG50 simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16217v1.summary: We present the properties of Milky Way- and Andromeda-like (MW/M31-like)galaxies simulated within TNG50. We present our selection for MW/M 31 analogs, which we propose for direct usage as well as for reference in future analyses. The majority of TNG 50 MW/ M31analogs at $z=0$ exhibit a bar, 60 per cent are star-forming.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16204v1.title: The Decoupling of Binaries from Their Circumbinary Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16204v1.summary: We have investigated accreting supermassive black hole binaries as they inspiral. Our simulations accurately capture the point at which the orbital evolving of each binary decouples from that of their circumbinary disk. We show that, even when dynamically negligible, gas may leave a detectable imprint on the phase of gravitational waves. If detected, such a decrease may unambiguously identify the host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16183v1.title: Aspect ratios of far-infrared and H i filaments in the diffuse interstellar medium at high Galactic latitudes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16183v1.summary: Dusty magnetized structures observable in the far-infrared (FIR) at high Galactic latitudes are ubiquitous. We trace individual filamentary structures along the plane of the sky and determine $A$ and $F$. Filaments in the diffuse interstellar medium (ISM) are seldom isolated, but are rather part of a network of filaments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13424v2.title: Improving the open cluster census. II. An all-sky cluster catalogue with Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13424v2.summary: We have conducted the largest search for open clusters to date, producing a single homogeneous star cluster catalogue. The catalogue's distribution traces the galactic warp, the spiral arm structure, and the dust distribution of the Milky Way. As many as a few thousand of our clusters are more compatible with unbound moving groups.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11971v2.title: Gaia Data Release 3: Gaia scan-angle dependent signals and spurious periods
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11971v2.summary: Gaia DR3 time series data may contain spurious signals related to the time-dependent scan angle. Source structure or pollution from close-by bright objects can cause biases in the image parameter determination from which photometric,astrometric and (indirectly) radial velocity time series are derived. A variety of statistics allows for the identification of affected sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16124v1.title: Search for lithium-rich giants in 32 open clusters with high-resolution spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16124v1.summary: Lithium-rich giant stars are rare and their existence challenges our understanding of stellar structure and evolution. We profit from a high-quality sample gathered with HARPS and UVES in order to search for Li-rich giants and to identify the Li enrichment mechanisms responsible. We have found 14 canonicalLi- rich giant stars which have experienced the first dredge-up.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16121v1.title: Detection of ethanol, acetone, and propanal in TMC-1: New O-bearing complex organics in cold sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16121v1.summary: Three O-bearing complex organic molecules are known to be present in warm interstellar clouds, but had never been observed in a starless core. The detections of ethanol, acetone, and propanal were made in the framework of QUIJOTE, a deep line survey of TMC-1 in the Q band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16070v1.title: Understanding the temperatures of H3+ and H2 in diffuse interstellar sightlines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16070v1.summary: Triatomic hydrogen ion H3+ is one of the most important species for the gas phase chemistry of the interstellar medium. However, the temperatures inferred from the two lowest rotationalstates of H3+. in diffuse lines of sight - typically the only ones observable - appear consistently lower than the temperatures derived from H2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16060v1.title: Distribution and Kinematics of H I through Raman He II Spectroscopy of NGC 6302
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16060v1.summary: The young planetary nebula NGC 6302 is known to exhibit Raman-scattered He IIfeatures at 6545 and 4851 Angstrom. These features are formed through inelasticscattering of He II with hydrogen atoms in the ground state. We adopt a simple scattering geometry consisting of a compact He II emission region surrounded by a H I medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16049v1.title: On the role of dust and mass loss in the extended main sequence turnoff of star clusters: the case of NGC 1783
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16049v1.summary: Large Magellanic Cloud Cluster NGC 1783 shows the presence of a small group of UV-dim stars. These stars are located at colors on the red side of the typical "fan" shape displayed by the eMSTO. We model the stars by assuming that some of the stars are obscured by a ring of dust due to grain condensation at the periphery of the excretion disc. A reasonably low optical depth at 10$\mu$ is necessary to model the UV-Dim group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16020v1.title: The SAMI-Fornax Dwarfs Survey III: Evolution of [$α$/Fe] in dwarfs, from Galaxy Clusters to the Local Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16020v1.summary: Using very deep, high spectral resolution data from the SAMI Integral Field Spectrograph we study the stellar population properties of a sample of dwarf galaxies in the Fornax Cluster. We find that the mass-metallicity relation is not linear. The relation between [$\alpha$/Fe] and stellar mass can be understood in the following way: when the faintest galaxies enter the cluster environment, a rapid burst of starformation is induced, after which the gas content is blown away.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01948v2.title: An empirical relation to estimate host galaxy stellar light from AGN spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01948v2.summary: Measurement of black hole mass for low-$z$ ($z\leq 0.8$) Active Galactic                Nuclei (AGNs) is difficult due to the strong contribution from host galaxystellar light. Here, we present an empirical relation to estimate host galaxy                stellar luminosity from the optical spectra of AGNs at $z $0.8$. We fit the AGN power-law continuum, host galaxy, and iron blend contribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15894v1.title: The mass accretion history of dark matter haloes down to Earth mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15894v1.summary: The formation redshift of low-mass haloes anti-correlates weakly with mass. At the higher masses, the correlation between local environment density and MAH is relatively weak. All models fit our simulations reasonably well over the mass range for which they were calibrated. The analytical models do better when extrapolated down to Earth mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v1.title: Refining the 2022 OJ 287 impact flare arrival epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v1.summary: The 2022 impact flare, namely flare number 26, is rather peculiar as it breaks the typical pattern of two impact flares per 12-year cycle. This is the third bremsstrahlung flare of the current cycle that follows the already-observed 2015 and 2019 impact flares from OJ~287.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15853v1.title: The interplay between feedback, accretion, transport and winds in setting gas-phase metal distribution in galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15853v1.summary: In this work, we model the relative role of star formation feedback, gas transport, cosmic gasaccretion, and galactic winds in driving radial metallicity profiles and setting the mass-metallicity gradient relation. While the mass loading of galactic winds is important to producing the MZR, we find that metal mass loading is more important to reproducing MZGR in low-mass galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15794v1.title: Machine Learning for Observational Cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15794v1.summary: An array of large observational programs using ground-based and space-bornetelescopes is planned in the next decade. The forthcoming wide-field skysurveys are expected to deliver a sheer volume of data exceeding an exabyte. Fully automated technologies based on machine learning and artificial intelligence are urgently needed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15769v1.title: Carbon-Chain Chemistry in the Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15769v1.summary: The presence of carbon-chain molecules in the interstellar medium has been known since the early 1970s. More complex species of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and fullerenes have been detected in circumstellar envelopes around carbon-rich stars and planetary nebulae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15767v1.title: Dark Matter in Fractional Gravity I: Astrophysical Tests on Galactic Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15767v1.summary: We explore the possibility that the dark matter (DM) component in grotesquegalaxies may originate fractional gravity. In such a framework, the standardlaw of inertia continues to hold, but the gravitational potential associated to a given DM density distribution is determined by a modified Poisson equation. We show that the dynamics of a test particle moving in a cuspyNFW density distribution are substantially altered with respect to the Newtonian case.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15695v1.title: Insights on the Sun birth environment in the context of star-cluster formation in hub-filament systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15695v1.summary: Cylindrical molecular filaments are observed to be the main sites of Sun-like star formation. Massive stars form in dense hubs, at the junction of multiple filaments. The host filament can shield the young solar system from stellar feedback, both during the formation and evolution of stars and at the end of their life.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14886v2.title: An Extensive Catalog of Early-type Dwarf Galaxies in the Local Universe: Morphology and Environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14886v2.summary: We present an extensive catalog of 5405 early-type dwarf (dE) galaxies. The dEs are selected through visual inspection of the Legacy survey's $g$-$r$-$z$ combined tri-color images. The strength of the catalog lies in the morphologicalcharacteristics, including nucleated, tidal, and ultradiffuse dE.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15664v1.title: Synthetic Population of Binary Cepheids. II. The effect of companion light on the extragalactic distance scale
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15664v1.summary: classical Cepheids play a key role in the calibration of the extragalactic distance scale and thedetermination of the Hubble-Lema constant $H_0. We find that while all PLRs are shifted toward brighter values due to the excess light from the companions, the bias in the relative distance modulus between two galaxies can be either positive or negative.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.00661v2.title: Synthetic population of binary Cepheids. I. The effect of metallicity and initial parameter distribution on characteristics of Cepheids' companions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.00661v2.summary: The majority of classical Cepheids are binary stars, yet the contribution of their light to the total brightness of the system has been assumednegligible and lacked a thorough, quantitative evaluation. We present an extensive study of synthetic populations of binary Cep heids that aims to quantify their contribution to the brightness and color of Cepheid binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05135v2.title: Photometric calibration in u-band using blue halo stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05135v2.summary: The galactic halo stars belong to an oldstellar population of the Milky Way and have relatively low metallicity. The "blue tip" of the halo population -- the main sequence turn-off (MSTO) stars -- is known to have a relatively uniform intrinsic edge u-g color.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03801v2.title: Multiple Flares in the Changing-Look AGN NGC 5273
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03801v2.summary: NGC 5273 is a known optical and X-ray variable AGN. At least one optical changing-look event occurred between 2011 and 2014. It then faded considerably at all wavelengths, followed by a dramatic increase in UV/optical brightness between 2021 and 2022. We propose that the variable luminosity (and thus the Eddington ratio) of the source is changing how the broad line region (BLR) reprocesses the continuum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15618v1.title: Revisiting Emission-Line Measurement Methods for Narrow-Line Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15618v1.summary: Measuring broad emission-line widths in active galactic nuclei (AGN) is not straightforward owing to the complex nature of flux variability in these systems. Line-width measurements become especially challenging when signal-to-noise is low, profiles are narrower, or spectral resolution is low. We discovered that allowing the narrow-line flux of permitted lines to vary during spectralfitting caused a leak in the broad component.
