As the first luminous structures, these stars seed the first galaxies and begin the process of reionization. We construct an analytic model to self-consistently trace theformation of Pop III stars inside minihalos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03258v1.title: Introducing the Texas Euclid Survey for Lyman Alpha (TESLA) Survey: Initial Study Correlating Galaxy Properties to Lyman-Alpha Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03258v1.summary: The Texas Euclid Survey for Lyman-Alpha (TESLA) is a spectroscopic survey in the 10 square degree of the Euclid North Ecliptic Pole (NEP) field. Using TESLA, we study how the physical properties of Ly man-alpha emitters (LAEs) correlate with Lymanalpha emission to understand the escape of LymanAlpha from galaxies at redshifts 2 -- 3.5. We present an analysis of 43 LAEs performed in the NEP field using early data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01015v2.title: The origin of ultramassive white dwarfs: hints from Gaia EDR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01015v2.summary: Gaia Data Release 2 revealed a population of ultramassive white dwarfs on the                Q branch that are moving anomalously fast for a local disc population with young photometric ages. As the velocity dispersion of stars in the localdisc increases with age, a proposed explanation of these white dwarffs is that they experience a cooling delay.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v2.title: A model for the infrared-radio correlation of main-sequence galaxies at GHz frequencies and its dependence on redshift and stellar mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v2.summary: The infrared-radio correlation (IRRC) of star-forming galaxies can be used to estimate their star formation rate (SFR) based on radio luminosity. For application in future deep radiosurveys, it is crucial to know whether the IRRC persists at high redshift z.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v2.title: One Relation for All Wavelengths: The Far-Ultraviolet to Mid-Infrared Milky Way Spectroscopic R(V) Dependent Dust Extinction Relationship
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v2.summary: Dust extinction is one of the fundamental measurements of dust grain sizes, Compositions, and shapes. Most of the wavelength dependent variations seen in Milky Way extinction are strongly correlated with the single parameter R(V)=A(V)/E(B-V. Existing literature relationships show significant deviations compared to this relationship especially in the far-ultraviolet and mid-infrared. We find tentative evidence that the relationship may not be linear with A(V)/R(V.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07668v2.title: Constraining axion and compact dark matter with interstellar medium heating
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07668v2.summary: Cold interstellar gas systems have been used to constrain dark matter (DM) models by the condition that the heating rate from DM must be lower than the cooling rate of the gas. We use the interstellar medium of a gas-rich dwarf galaxy, Leo                T, and a Milky Way-environment gas cloud, G33.4-8.0. Our limits are complementary to DM direct detection metrics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v2.title: A Diverse Population of z ~ 2 ULIRGs Revealed by JWST Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v2.summary: Four ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) observed with JWST/NIRcam in the Cosmos Evolution Early Release Science program. The objects were originally selected at 24                $\mu$m and have strong polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon emission features. The four objects have similar stellar masses but otherwise are quite diverse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03058v1.title: A VLT/VIMOS view of two $Planck$ multiple-cluster systems: structure and galaxy properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03058v1.summary: We analysed spectroscopic data obtained with VLT-VIMOS for two multiple-cluster systems. We found that the two systems are populated mainly with passive galaxies. We also find evidence for remaining star formation activity in the highest-redshift cluster of PLCKG$214.6+36.9$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v2.title: Refining the 2022 OJ 287 impact flare arrival epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v2.summary: The 2022 impact flare, namely flare number 26, is rather peculiar as it breaks the typical pattern of two impact flares per 12-year cycle. This is the third bremsstrahlung flare of the current cycle that follows the already-observed 2015 and 2019 impact flares from OJ~287.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v2.title: Fundamental effective temperature measurements for eclipsing binary stars -- IV. Selection of new benchmark stars and first results for HD 22064
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v2.summary: HD22064 is an ideal benchmark star for "end-to-end" tests of the stellar parameters measured by large-scalespectroscopic surveys. The techniques described here for HD22064 can be applied to the other eclipsing binaries in the sample in order to create an all-sky network of such benchmark stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12970v2.title: Abundance ratios of OH/CO and HCO+/CO as probes of the cosmic ray ionization rate in diffuse clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12970v2.summary: The cosmic-ray ionization rate (CRIR) is one of the key parameters controlling the formation and destruction of various molecules in molecularclouds. The current most commonly used CRIR tracers, such as H$_3^+$, are hard to detect and require the presence of background massive stars for absorption measurements. We propose an alternative method to infer the CRIR in diffuse clouds using the abundance of OH/CO and HCO$^+$/CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02997v1.title: Right-Handed Neutrino Dark Matter with Forbidden Annihilation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02997v1.summary: The seesaw mechanism with three right-handed neutrinos has one as a well-motivated dark matter candidate if stable. The other two can explain asymmetry via the thermal leptogenesis scenario. We explore the possibility of introducing additional particles to make the right- handed Neutrino dark matter in thermal equilibrium and freeze out through a forbiddenihilation channel.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07059v2.title: KDG 64: a large dwarf spheroidal or a small ultradiffuse satellite of Messier 81
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07059v2.summary: Low-mass early-type galaxies, including dwarf spheroidals (dSph) and brighter dwarf ellipticals (dE), dominate the galaxy population in groups and clusters. KDG 64 is a local analogue of smaller UDGs in the Coma and Virgo clusters and is probably a transitional dSph-UDG object.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02969v1.title: The fastest hot subdwarfs revisited
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02969v1.summary: Hyper-velocity stars (HVS) are enigmatic objects because they are travelling so fast that they escape from the Galaxy. Among hot subdwarfs, only one such star is known, the He-sdO US 708. The Hyper-MUCHFUSS collaboration provided additional HVS candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02958v1.title: Spatial metallicity variations of mono-temperature stellar populations revealed by early-type stars in LAMOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02958v1.summary: We investigate the radial metallicity gradients on the Galactocentric $X$--$Y$ plane. We also identify five potential metal-poor substructures with large metalicity excess dispersions. High-velocity clouds are not well mixed with the pre-existing Galactic disk ISM within 0.3\,Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v3.title: Model-Independent Mass Reconstruction of the Hubble Frontier Field Clusters with MARS Based on Self-Consistent Strong Lensing Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v3.summary: We present new strong-lensing (SL) mass reconstruction of the six HubbleFrontier Fields (HFF) clusters with the MAximum-entropy ReconStruction (MARS) algorithm. With $100-200$ multiple images per cluster, we construct solutions with small scatters of multiple images in both source and image planes. We find that in general, these mass hypertpeaks are in excellent spatial agreement with the member galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02907v1.title: The new detection of blue straggler stars in 50 open clusters using Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02907v1.summary: The presence of blue straggler stars (BSS) in Galacticopen clusters offers favorable conditions for detailed studies. With the help of Gaia DR3, the number of identified open clusters continuouslyincreases, and the determination of star cluster members is more reliable. We identified 138 BSS that had not been reported before in 50 open clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02857v1.title: A MUSE view of the multiple interacting system HCG 31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02857v1.summary: We present, for the first time, spatially resolved spectroscopy for the entire Hickson Compact Group 31. We derived radial velocity and dispersion velocitymaps, maps of the ionization mechanism of the system, chemical abundances and their distribution over the whole system. We also reconstructed the star formation history of the four galaxies in the group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02815v1.title: MOA-2022-BLG-249Lb: Nearby microlensing super-Earth planet detected from high-cadence surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02815v1.summary: The lensing eventMOA-2022-BLG-249 exhibits a brief positive anomaly that lasted for about 1 day. The anomaly is better explained by the planetary model than thebinary-source model. The planet detection demonstrates the elevatedmicrolensing sensitivity of the current high-cadence lensing surveys to low-mass planets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02803v1.title: Witnessing a Transformation to Blue-cored Dwarf Early-type Galaxies in Filaments and the Cluster Outskirts: Gas-phase Abundances and Internal Kinematics Perspectives
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02803v1.summary: The presence of transitional dwarf galaxies in filaments and clusteroutskirts may be closely related to pre-processing in the filament. The underlying mechanism is not yet comprehensively understood. We present the chemical and kinematical properties of three blue-cored early-type galaxies (dE(bc)s) in the Virgo cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.02876v2.title: Small-scale clumping of dark matter and the mean free path of ionizing photons at $z=6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.02876v2.summary: The mean free path of ionizing photons in the $z = 6$ intergalacticmedium (IGM) was measured to be very short, presenting a challenge to existing cosmology models. We use two classes of models to contrast against the standard CDM prediction: (1) thermal relic warm matter (WDM), representing models with suppressed small-scale power; (2) ultralight axion exhibiting a white noise-like power enhancement.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11266v2.title: The Morphology of Reionization in a Dynamically Clumpy Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11266v2.summary: A recent measurement of the Lyman-limit mean free path at $z = 6$ suggests it may have been very short. We address this question with a dynamical sub-grid model for the sinks based on radiative hydrodynamics simulations. Compared to assuming a fullypressure-smoothed IGM, our dynamical treatment reduces ionized bubble sizes by $10-20%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02784v1.title: Strong Lensed QSOs with Variability Detectable by LSST: How many are there?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02784v1.summary: Strong lensed quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) are valuable probes of the tumultuous universe. The Vera C. Rubin Telescope Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) uses QSOs for reverberation mapping and time delay measurements. We expect 30--40% of the mock lensed QSO sample, which corresponds to $1,000, to exhibit variability detectable with LSST.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02779v1.title: Hyades Member K2-136c: The Smallest Planet in an Open Cluster with a Precisely Measured Mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02779v1.summary: K2-136 is a late-K dwarf in the Hyades open cluster with three known, transiting planets and an age of $650\pm70$ Myr. The planets K1-136b, c, and d have periods of $8.0, $17.3, and $25.6$ days and radii of $1.014, $3.13, and$1.565. Mass estimates may be feasible with more radial velocity observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02684v1.title: Cosmic ray propagation in turbulent magnetic fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02684v1.summary: Propagation of cosmic rays (CRs) in turbulent and magnetized astrophysical media is a long-standing problem. This review focuses on selected recent theoretical findings made. In particular, we address the problem of perpendicular and parallelpropagation. We identify the conditions when the perpendicular propagation is superdiffusive and diffusive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02666v1.title: Early Results from GLASS-JWST XXIII: The transmission of Lyman-alpha from UV-faint z ~ 3-6 galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02666v1.summary: Lyman-alpha (Ly$\alpha$) emission from galaxies can be used to trace neutralHydrogen in the epoch of reionization. There is a degeneracy between the attenuation of Ly$\ alpha$ in the intergalactic medium (IGM) and the line                profile emitted from the galaxy. Large shifts of the systemic redshift of galaxies can boost Ly$ \alpha$ transmission in the interstellar medium.
